history.content: I prefer cs188. Now that you have taken ee16a and ee16b, math 110 is kind of redundant. ee16a and ee16b well prepare for eecs 127.

children.subject: Thank you for the information! How is the course load for the class?

Usually upper div math classes have a lot less "required" work compared to CS or EE classes but can have very difficult homeworks and the concepts are often much harder to understand at a first glance. I think the workload will depend based on how familiar you are with proofs and you may have to spend a lot of time rereading the textbook and practice proof writing.
What textbook is typically used for Math 110? And do you know of any resources to practice proof writing?

Linear Algebra by Friedberg is most commonly used since it is very rigorous but it is often hard to read. I would recommend looking at Linear Algebra Done Right by Axler as well. For proof writing, I would take a look at An Introduction to Mathematical Arguments by Hutchings and definitely look at CS70 material if you haven't taken 70 yet.

Personally I would recommend taking Math 110 especially if you feel rough on your proof maturity and plan on taking courses such as EE 127 or CS 189. Contentwise, almost everything covered in EE16AB is already covered in Math 110. However, Math 110 is miles away from EE16AB / Math 54 in the way the material is presented. Since it's an upper division math class, everything will be proved and you will be expected to write clear and concise proofs. There is very little computation compared to the other linear algebra courses since Math 54 is technically a prerequisite. It's a great class if you really want to solidify your linear algebra intuition and improve your proof writing skills. Plus I hear Olga Holtz is teaching 110 so you'll definitely get a lot out of the class.
Thank you for sharing your experience, this really helps!

I took math1b, math 53, cs70, and stat140 and even after all of that I still felt like my proof writing was pretty shit. 

I took math110 this fall and saw a dramatic increase in my proof writing skills. 

Even though 70 was supposed to teach me some proof writing skills I still struggled for some reason - all of the proofs felt like too big of a jump from what I knew/ the textbook and I would always stare at it with no ideas and then become really frustrated (I think this was more of a "my own brain" problem rather than the course structure though ). 

But in math110, the homework problems from the Friedberg textbook were great mid - level proofs. They were slightly more advanced than the proofs shown in lecture, but used the same ideas / patterns, so I was actually able to solve a lot of them on my own. At the end of the semester, I looked back on the problems I worked on and my performance on the exams and saw an increase in problem solving and proof writing ability, so not only did I enjoy Math110 for the content, I developed some valuable skills. 

(Side note: we didn't actually turn in the hw for math110 this fall but I highly recommend attempting all the problems on your own - its amazing practice. I am still shaky on the one section whose homework I didn't do). 

(Side note #2: If you haven't taken 70/math 55 yet, I recommend reading  note 1 and note 2 from cs70 before starting math110 because the professor occasionally used some terms like "contrapostive" that tripped a few people up in the first few weeks. )  

I haven't taken 188 so I can't comment on that.

history.content: Would it be more wise to take CS 188 or Math 110 in the spring? I feel a little bit rough on my proof maturity and performed at the "B" level for both EE16A and EE16B (so my linear algebra skills can use a bit of work). My original intent for taking CS 188 was to introduce me to artificial intelligence concepts, but, in future semesters, I plan on taking courses such as EE 127 (whilst leaning slightly towards EE courses like 128 and 106) (may also plan to take 189).
history.subject: CS188 or Math 110?
